data.name: Acne
data.overview:
A skin condition that occurs when hair follicles plug with oil and dead skin cells.
Acne is most common in teenagers and young adults.
Symptoms range from uninflamed blackheads to pus-filled pimples or large, red and tender bumps.
Treatments include over-the-counter creams and cleanser, as well as prescription antibiotics.
data.symptoms: Symptoms range from uninflamed blackheads to pus-filled pimples or large, red and tender bumps.
data.treatment: Treatments include over-the-counter creams and cleanser, as well as prescription antibiotics.

data.name: Actinic keratosis
data.overview:
A rough, scaly patch on the skin caused by years of sun exposure.
Actinic keratoses usually affects older adults. Reducing sun exposure can help reduce risk.
It is most common on the face, lips, ears, back of hands, forearms, scalp and neck. The rough, scaly skin patch enlarges slowly and usually causes no other signs or symptoms. A lesion may take years to develop.
Because it can become cancerous, it's usually removed as a precaution.
data.symptoms:
Requires a medical diagnosis
It is most common on the face, lips, ears, back of hands, forearms, scalp and neck. The rough, scaly skin patch enlarges slowly and usually causes no other signs or symptoms. A lesion may take years to develop.
data.treatment: Because it can become cancerous, it's usually removed as a precaution.

data.name: Eczema
data.overview: Eczema is a skin condition that causes dry and itchy patches of skin. It’s a common condition that isn’t contagious.
data.symptoms: Symptoms of eczema can flare up if you contact an irritant or an allergen.
data.treatment: There are treatments available to help you manage symptoms, but there isn’t a cure

data.name: Melanoma
data.overview:
The most serious type of skin cancer.
Melanoma occurs when the pigment-producing cells that give colour to the skin become cancerous.
Symptoms might include a new, unusual growth or a change in an existing mole. Melanomas can occur anywhere on the body.
data.symptoms:
Requires a medical diagnosis
Symptoms might include a new, unusual growth or a change in an existing mole. Melanomas can occur anywhere on the body.
data.treatment:
Treatment depends on stage
Treatment may involve surgery, radiation, medication or in some cases, chemotherapy.

data.name: Tinea Ringworm
data.overview:
A highly contagious fungal infection of the skin or scalp.
Ringworm is spread by skin-to-skin contact or by touching an infected animal or object.
Ringworm is typically scaly and may be red and itchy. Ringworm of the scalp is common in children, where it may cause bald patches.
data.symptoms:
Usually self-diagnosable
Ringworm is typically scaly and may be red and itchy. Ringworm of the scalp is common in children, where it may cause bald patches.
data.treatment:
Treatment consists of self care and antifungals
The treatment for ringworm is antifungal medication.

data.name: Warts Molluscum
data.overview:
A viral skin infection that results in round, firm, painless bumps.
The condition spreads through contact with an infected person or a contaminated object.
Though painless, the small bumps might itch. Scratched bumps can spread infection to surrounding skin.
data.symptoms:
Requires a medical diagnosis
Though painless, the small bumps might itch. Scratched bumps can spread infection to surrounding skin.
data.treatment:
Treatment consists of procedures
The bumps usually disappear on their own. In rare cases, the bumps can be removed using medication or other procedures.

data.name: Vascular Tumors
data.overview: A vascular tumor is a tumor of vascular origin; a soft tissue growth that can be either benign or malignant, formed from blood vessels or lymph vessels.
data.symptoms: An area of spidery veins or lightened or discolored skin may appear before the hemangioma does.
data.treatment: Treatment may involve surgery, radiation, medication or in some cases, chemotherapy
